column1: ultraindia_desc;With the Prussian threat to our borders defanged for now
column2: India divided
column3: and the Ming on the brink of collapse
column4: we now have a perfect opportunity to finally focus the brunt of our attention to the rich lands of the Orient we've long considered secondary to our interests in Europe. Of particular interest to our merchants in the Bengal region are the Kalian highlands
column5: home to scores of mountain tribes keen on raiding our coastal concessions
column7: and the key to permanently securing our position in the Far East. However
column8: while there's no doubt we'll be able to bring Kale to heel on their own
column9: the Kingdom of Kale is still technically a tributary of the Ming Empire and
column11: it's doubtful that the Chinese will simply abandon their tributaries while their right to rule is under growing scrutiny. Our minister have been warned that another long
column12: protracted war with the Ming in the Kalian jungles and mountains could prove ruinous for our frail economy. Demanding Ming withdrawal would simplify matters considerably but
column14: we shall have to prepare for the worst.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: EVTDESC7790001;The Southeast Asia is a harsh land
column2: covered in dense jungles
column4: and vast rivers. Borders in this region are hard to agree on
column6: and near impossible to enforce.\nThe latter two are what we are now using to legitimise our push into the Kalian highlands in violation of our earlier treaty with the Ming Empire. While Nanjing is unlikely to be appeased by our justifications
column7: it does give the battered empire an out of the situation while saving us the trouble of a large-scale land war in Asia.\nAll we have left to do is wait for our representative in Nanjing to bring back the Chinese Emperor's response...;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: EVTOPTB7790001;Jungle warfare in Southeast Asia? Maybe that's not the best idea...;;;;;;;;;;;;;x
EVTDESC7790002;"...the border shall be delineated at the Mekong
column2: with a demilitarised zone of 50 km enforced on both sides of the river for the sake of free trade and amity between our two Empires..." \n\nEver since their victory in 1812
column3: French presence in Southeast Asia has been growing at an alarming rate. Now
column4: the French ambassador has approached us with a humiliating 'offer to settle our respective spheres of influence': in short
column5: surrender our tributary Kale in return for peace. Worse
column6: it comes with the stipulation that this 'treaty' can be revised every 15 years without clearly stating what clauses can be revised and on what terms. The Kalians have in turn come to the Forbidden Palace
column7: beseeching the Emperor punish the French for their arrogance. Yet
column8: having lost to the French once already and with the growing Korean threat to the north
column9: can we really spare the effort to fight another war with no clear benefit for us?;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: EVTOPTA7790002;Kale isn't worth the cost. The French can do as they please.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x
EVTOPTB7790002;Those barbarians must be put in their place
column2: at any cost!;;;;;;;;;;;;;x
the Ming have rejected our proposal outright and have openly declared their support for the Kingdom of Kale. We've but one option left.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x
you forget our other option.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x
the Ming have agreed to our demands: Kale is ours to do as we see fit. And
column4: we've retained our right to revise our sphere of influence.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: EVTOPT7790004;Who knew Kale could taste so sweet;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

EVTDESC7790005;"...the Kingdoms of Kale and Hsipaw shall be under French guidance while the Kingdom of Lan Xang and the Sundanese Isles shall be made free and independent nations that shall conduct their own diplomatic agenda and operate without any interference from the Chinese Empire. Additionally
column2: the island of Hainan shall be ceded to the French Empire as collatoral guaranteeing the maintainance of the treaty's guidelines for a duration of 99 years..."\n\nFor years
column3: the Chinese have passed the results of the first Sino-French War off as a fluke. However
column4: with our second victory over the Ming
column5: it's clear that French military superiority over the Chinese has transcended mere warroom opinion and become indisputable truth. Backed by superior soldiers and more advanced arms
column6: we're at liberty to enforce our full demands on UltraIndia and eastern trade.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: EVTOPT7790005;And so the French Eagle rises!;;;;;;;;;;;;;x
EVTDESC7790006;We have lost. Try as we might
column2: we cannot ignore the red Kalian highlands
column3: stained with the blood of thousands of our men
column4: nor the thundering barbarian guns that painted the mountains with gusto. While our generals bicker over the cause of our defeat
column5: whether the Kalians betrayed us or poor decision making by field commanders
column6: all we can do is wait and see the fallout of this inauspicious day;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: EVTOPT7790006;Dark days lie ahead of us...;;;;;;;;;;;;;x
EVTDESC7790007;One last crack of gunpowder rang out in the air before it became clear that the only French flags left were those black and red
column2: trampled into the mud and soaked through with French blood. In the distance
column3: grand French ships sat impotently far from the coast
column4: slowly turning westward. A moment of silence
column6: gave way to a grand wave of cheers heard throughout every valley in the Kalian highlands: OUR HOMELAND! OUR FREEDOM! VICTORY AT LAST!\n\nWith this great victory
column7: we've both demolished the French position in Southeast Asia and proven to the world the era of the Ming is far from over. Our hegemony over Southeast Asia now confirmed
column8: we can expel the foreign dogs from our subjects' lands and revive our Mandate to rule!;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: EVTOPT7790007;And so the Dragon awakens once more!;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column2: so much gold
column3: for nothing more than a scrap of paper taking away our lands and influence in Southeast Asia. It seems our imperial ambitions in this region must
column5: come to an end. We can only hope that this is all we lose as we rebuild and recover from this loss.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: hainan_treaty_port_desc;The city of Zhuya (Shore of Pearls)
column2: name for the famous pearl fisheries of the region
column3: now known as Qiongshan is an important stop to Shanghai and Formosa. Controlling it would give control over all of Hainan and would make an important coaling station.;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: taipei_treaty_port_desc;The Taipei area is where the major Han Chinese settlements in northern Taiwan and one of the designated overseas trade ports
column2: Tamsui
column3: are located. The area gained economic importance due to the booming overseas trade
column4: especially that of tea export. Controlling it would mean controlling Taiwan and a good amount of the tea trade.;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: jiaxing_treaty_port_desc;Jiaxing is well known as the 'hometown of silk' and it's a famous producer of textiles and woolens. While not being as important as neighboring Shanghai
column2: its acquisition would surely help our textile industry.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: weihaiwei_treaty_port_desc;The port of Weihaiwei serves as the base for the Beiyang Fleet (Northern Seas Fleet) for the Qing Dynasty. Along with Lüshun
column2: it provides a strategic point for the control of the Korea Bay and the Bohai Gulf. Controlling it would put our fleets at the door of the imperial capital of China.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: lushun_treaty_port_desc;Sprawling around the narrowest neck of the Liaodong Peninsula
column2: occupying the Southern Tip
column5: is in a crucial point. It guards the entrance the Imperial Capital of China and the Bohai Sea. Controlling it would provide a strategical hold on the Bohai Gulf and the Korean Bay.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: qingdao_treaty_port_desc;Qingdao is a sleepy fishing town undergoing dramatic changes - a naval station and garrisons were built by the rulers of the Qing dynasty and the increasing presence of western ships is increasing its importance. It would be an splendid gateway to northern China.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column2: shipping
column4: Shanghai grew in importance in the 19th century due to European recognition of its favorable port location and economic potential. This potential can be fully realized under $COUNTRY_ADJ$ administration.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: hong_kong_treaty_port_desc;China is the main supplier of its native tea to Europe
column2: whose annual domestic consumption reached 30
column7: an average of 1.036 pounds (0.470 kg) per head of population. From the $COUNTRY_ADJ$ economic standpoint
column8: Chinese tea was a crucial item since it provides massive wealth for the taipans — foreign (especially $COUNTRY_ADJ$) businessmen in China — while the duty on tea accounted for 10% of the government's income. With a base in Hong Kong our tea and opium trade will profit immensely and the city will
column10: bring us a lot of profit.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: macao_treaty_port_desc;Macao lies on the western side of the Pearl River Delta across from Hong Kong. If we are to access the riches of Guangdong and the south of China
column2: controlling Macao would be a good start.;;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column1: ningbo_treaty_port_desc;Ningbo is one of China's oldest cities
column2: with a history dating to the Hemudu culture in 4800 BC. Ningbo was known as a trade city on the silk road at least two thousand years ago
column3: and then as a major port
column4: along with Yangzhou and Guangzhou in the Tang Dynasty
column6: the major ports for foreign trade in the Song Dynasty. A walled city sandwiched between the ocean and low-lying mountains to the southwest
column7: with coastal plain and valleys in between
column8: it plays an important role in controlling the important peninsulas of Chuanshan and Xiangshan Peninsula. During the Ming and Qing Dynasties
column9: the textile industry flourished in Ningbo.;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column2: south of Korea
column3: lies in the Korea Strait between Japan and Korea. According to the local legend
column4: three demigods emerged from Samsung which is said to have been on the northern slopes of Mt. Halla and became the progenitors of the Jeju people who founded the Kingdom of Tamna. During the Joseon Dynasty of Korea Jeju islanders were treated as foreigners and Jeju was considered as a place for horse breeding and exile for political prisoners. In the 17th Century
column5: Injo of Joseon issued an edict prohibiting islanders from traveling to the Korean mainland. Despite the poverty
column6: the Island would serve as a good base to exert influence over Korea and Japan and it's the place that's more likely to be ceded - the current owners don't care about it too much.;;;;;;;;;;;;x

column2: coming from zangi
column3: a Persian name of a local people
column5:
and the Persian bar, which means coast or shore. The Zanzibar Archipelago consists of several islands lying off the coast of East Africa in the Indian Ocean. There are three main islands plus a number of smaller islets that surround them and an isolated tiny islet. Zanzibar is the center of the Arab slave trade and projects its power over a long strip of land in Eastern Africa. It would serve as an excellent base of operations and coaling station in East Africa.;;;;;;;;;;;;x,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,
socotra_treaty_port_title;The Socotra Island Concession;;;;;;;;;;;;x,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,
socotra_treaty_port_desc;A small archipelago of four islands in the Indian Ocean, Socotra has been inhabited since the 1st-century AD, appearing as Dioskouridou (of the Dioscuri") in the Periplus of the Erythraean Sea
column6: a Greek navigation aid. The main city of the island is called Hadibu and with a garrison
column8: the island would be an ideal place for a coaling station for our ships coming and going from India and Eastern Africa.;;;;;;;;;;;;x
